isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: SHEPPARD M-SERIES - REASSEMBLE

step1.para: The M-series models use a seal ring on the end of the power piston. A new seal is installed by placing the back-up O-ring in the piston groove and installing the square cut seal ring over it ( Figure 90).

figure.caption: Figure 90. Install Square Cut Seal Ring

note.para: The seal material will stretch as it is fitted to the ring groove. If you let the piston set with the seal rings in place, it will become easier to install it in the piston bore. Use of a ring compressor is best to limit damage to the piston ring.

step1.para: Install a new sector shaft seal in the housing. Make sure the blue side of the seal is toward the outside of the housing ( Figure 91).

figure.caption: Figure 91. Install New Sector Shaft Seal

note.para: The housing will have a beveled chamfer on one end of the piston housing only. The piston will be installed through that end of the housing. Light taps with a soft hammer may be required on the end of piston to move it into the housing.

step1.para: At this time, you can re-assemble the gear. Before installation of the piston into the piston bore of the housing, check for burrs on either the piston or piston bore. If burrs are present, they may be removed by polishing with a fine handstone or crocus cloth.
Coat both the piston and piston bore of the housing with a light coat of motor oil.
Carefully insert the piston into the piston bore of the housing, keeping the ball guide cavity exposed as shown ( Figure 92).

figure.caption: Figure 92. Insert Piston into Piston Bore

caution.para: Care must be taken when installing the piston in the housing. Close tolerances may cause the piston to jam in the housing bore. Any attempt to force the piston at that time could cause nicking or gouging of the housing bore.

step1.para: Install a new seal ring on the bearing cap and actuating shaft assembly ( Figure 93).

figure.caption: Figure 93. Install New Seal Ring

note.para: Cover the new seal ring with a light coat of grease to keep it in place during assembly.

step1.para: Insert the bearing cap and actuating shaft assembly into the piston as shown ( Figure 94).

figure.caption: Figure 94. Insert Bearing Cap and Actuating Shaft Assembly

note.para: Do not insert the bearing cap assembly completely. The bearing cap must be inserted to within 3 inches of the end of the piston.

step1.para: Install both halves of the ball guide into the ball guide cavity ( Figure 95).

figure.caption: Figure 95. Install Both Halves of Ball Guide

caution.para: Make sure the ball guides are pushed into the cavity all the way. Failure to do so during installation will result in the ball guides being pushed out of the piston during assembly. This will cause the balls to come out of track and binding will result.

step1.para: While supporting the bearing cap assembly with your hand, load the 24 steel balls in the ball guide. Slowly turn the bearing cap assembly inward while feeding the steel balls until all the steel balls are used ( Figure 96).

figure.caption: Figure 96. Load Steel Balls in Ball Guide

caution.para: Do not attempt to back the actuating shaft out of the piston during this process. This will cause the steel balls to bind on the actuating shaft and shaft damage may result.

important.para: Both halves of the ball guide must be held down when loading the balls to prevent the balls from coming out of their track.

step1.para: Install a new O-ring on the ball guide retainer and coat it with a small amount of grease. Insert the retainer over the ball return guide and into the ball guide cavity ( Figure 97).

figure.caption: Figure 97. Insert Retainer Over Ball Return Guide

step1.para: It will be necessary to tap the ball guide retainer into place with a soft hammer ( Figure 98).

figure.caption: Figure 98. Tap Ball Guide Retainer into Place

important.para: When properly installed, the retainer will be flush with the piston contour.

step1.para: If a bolt-on retainer is used, replace the seal ring on the retainer and install it in the piston cavity. Install the mounting bolts ( Figure 99, Figure 100, and Figure 101).

figure.caption: Figure 99. Install Mounting Bolts
Figure 100. Install Mounting Bolts
Figure 101. Install Mounting Bolts

caution.para: The internal tooth lockwashers must be installed on the mounting bolts. Failure to use these washers will result in a loss of torque and a possible loss of power assist.

step1.para: Tighten bolts to 12 ft-lbs. (16 Nm).

To install the piston, carefully work the piston ring past the sector shaft opening in the cylinder bore. While maintaining pressure on the end of the piston, press the piston seal into the ring groove. As the piston ring is compressed into the ring groove, the piston will slide further into the bore until the piston ring has passed the sector shaft opening ( Figure 102 and Figure 103).

figure.caption: Figure 102. Work Piston Ring Past Sector Shaft Opening
Figure 103. Press Piston Seal into Ring

step1.para: Install a new tetra seal on the bearing cap assembly and attach the bearing cap to the housing ( Figure 104).

figure.caption: Figure 104. Install New Tetra Seal

note.para: A small amount of grease on the tetra seal will help hold it in place.

step1.para: Install the bearing cap with the 4 longest screws. Tighten to the torque value in the TORQUE CHART ( Figure 105).

figure.caption: Figure 105. Install Bearing Cap

note.para: If the bearing cap will not sit flush on the housing, be sure the bearing cap seal ring or tetra seal has not slipped out of place.

step1.para: Locate the timing mark on the piston rack and center the timing mark in the pinion bore of the housing by turning the actuating shaft ( Figure 106).

figure.caption: Figure 106. Locate Timing Mark on Piston Rack

step1.para: Install the sector shaft in the piston rack in the pinion bore.

important.para: The single timing mark on the sector shaft must line up between the two timing marks on the piston rack ( Figure 107).

figure.caption: Figure 107. Line Up Timing Marks

step1.para: It will be necessary to tap the end of the sector shaft with a soft hammer to make sure you have full rack and pinion engagement ( Figure 108).

figure.caption: Figure 108. Tap End of Sector Shaft

step1.para: Install a new sector shaft seal in the sector shaft cover ( Figure 109).

figure.caption: Figure 109. Install New Sector Shaft Seal

step1.para: Install the sector shaft cover and mounting bolts and tighten to values listed in the TORQUE CHART ( Figure 110).

figure.caption: Figure 110. Install Sector Shaft Cover

note.para: A light coat of oil on the sector shaft seal and cover seal ring will make installation easier.

step1.para: Place a new seal ring and tetra seal on the cylinder head ( Figure 111).

figure.caption: Figure 111. Place New Seal Ring and Tetra Seal on Cylinder Head

note.para: A light coat of grease on the seal ring and tetra seal will hold them in place during mounting.

step1.para: Attach the cylinder head to the housing using the four (4) remaining bolts. Tighten to specifications in the TORQUE CHART ( Figure 112).

figure.caption: Figure 112. Attach Cylinder Head to Housing

step1.para: Install the relief plungers in the cylinder head and bearing cap. Screw in the relief plungers till they are 1/8 inch (3.2 mm) below flush with the end caps ( Figure 113).

figure.caption: Figure 113. Install Relief Plungers

step1.para: Further adjustments are required. Refer to SET RELIEF PLUNGERS ( Figure 114).

figure.caption: Figure 114. Adjust Relief Plunger

important.para: When installing the stick-on dirt shield, it is important to thoroughly clean the housing with a suitable solvent.

step1.para: Apply a thin coat of RTV to the edge of the dirt shield and place it over the end of the sector shaft. Allow adequate time for RTV to set .
Attach the mounting bracket to the gear housing using the attaching bolts and tighten to values listed in the TORQUE CHART ( Figure 115) (if equipped).

figure.caption: Figure 115. Attach Mounting Bracket

step1.para: Pack the lip area of the sector shaft boot with grease and install it over the sector shaft. Install the boot on the input shaft and lubricate the grease fitting ( Figure 116).

figure.caption: Figure 116. Install Boot On Input Shaft

step1.para: If the steering gear has a pressed in excluder seal, pack the lip area with grease. Slide the excluder seal over the sector shaft with the lip facing out. Use a 2-1/4 inch seal driver to press the excluder seal into the cover. Clean the sector shaft splines before installing the pitman arm ( Figure 117).

figure.caption: Figure 117. Install Excluder Seal

step1.para: Install the steering gear on the vehicle.
Install the pitman arm on the steering gear. Refer to INSTALL section.
After installation on the vehicle, bleeding of the system may be necessary. Refer to BLEEDING section.
